body: Don't mind the above. The mvn also needed JAVA_HOME to be same as one in the toolchain. I'm pretty sure it was working with other version of maven.
If I open dialog with a `Link` in a new tab, it just blinks and disappears immediately (tested in FF, Chrome and Edge).
@svenmeier Right, I agree with what you say in #273. It would be nice to have some interface for extra header item attributes.
That's just AjaxNewWindowNotifyingBehavior creating a new page instance when it detects that you open a page in two different browser tabs.
@svenmeier is it close to what you suggested about the DecoratingHeaderResponse?
Yeah that's much simpler, isn't it? See my inline comments.
Thanks @martin-g ! There's another PR for the same issue https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/376 . Sven recommended to try different approach above.
@svenmeier @martin-g @solomax I pushed some after review improvements and fixed tests.

Thanks @svenmeier ! I'm waiting for comments then. 
This PR is pointing to wicket-8, I wanted to make it a non-breaking change. Potentially this can be first announced as a wicket-9 feature, and later be "retrofited" to the wicket-8.

Speaking about versions. I think that in wicket-8 this feature should produce same or almost the same HTML as before, but in wicket-9 we can drop charset of js, type of css and other deprecated things. There's a JIRA for the following cleanup https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/WICKET/issues/WICKET-6686

By the way. https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WICKET/Wicket+Source+Code+Style Is this one still somewhat up to date? It is really a pain for me to run Eclipse every time I want to format things. I configured styles in my IDEA according to this document.

I'll try to set up `apache-rat-plugin` and `maven-checkstyle-plugin`
to perform automatic checks and will prepare PR
This should unify things

> By the way. [cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WICKET/Wicket+Source+Code+Style](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WICKET/Wicket+Source+Code+Style) Is this one still somewhat up to date? It is really a pain for me to run Eclipse every time I want to format things. I configured styles in my IDEA according to this document.

I've setup IDEA to format only the lines I have edited.
Thank you everyone! I'll go through comments a bit later.
I went a bit further with cleaning names in utility classes and emphasized those which are inline ones, it was hard to remember which one does what even after reading the code.
I'm confused now - why shouldn't all attributes be escaped? I've read WICKET-4777 but I don't understand it.
@svenmeier I'm also confused. The url for the CSS is escaped, the url for JS is not. I have a solution, will push soon, once tests finished.
@svenmeier the issue, I think that escape markup simply swallows parameters spearated by &, because they are replaced with `&`
I suppose, the answer is generally that all URLs should be escaped and there, probably, must be a special header item which does accept script urls with parameters
I removed enums, and updated tests. It now produces the same output, including links for JS
I think this one should be closed.
We should reconsider the change introduced WICKET-4777 ... @martin-g can you explain why that JavScript url attribute should not be escaped?

WICKET-4777 is almost 7 years old. My memory capacity is not that big.

I guess my thinking was in the line of: If **Google** doesn't like Wicket's urls then Wicket should adapt, not the opposite.
We can try to revert it and see whether the browsers send non-escaped parameters.

Is `AttributeMap#compute(Object, Supplier)` still used ? 
I see you replaced all (?) callers to use the BiFunction variant. 
If there is no usage of the one with Supplier then let's remove it from the API
@martin-g the `AttributeMap#compute` has already been removed.
This PR is for wicket-8.x, I propose to merge it to the wicket-8.x with behavior replicating existing one. And to create another PR for wicket-9.x removing no-escape stuff for JS.

I think this isn't going to be possible with wicket 8. Pointed this PR to master.
@svenmeier please have a look at recent changes with using url encoding to escape content.

I'm not sure that what I did with url encoding is correct. Essentially all attributes have slightly different rule. 
Most of attributes may content anything except the quote matching opening quote, the ID attribute can contain anything except spaces and blank line.

I think the ValueMap#toString should only take care of quotes when rendering and escape them as appropriate. All other special escaping should be done by the developer in the header items, when added by a developer.
Pushed another commit removing escaping from the ValueMap and delegating this job to appropriate header items
#376 should open a relatively easy way for integrity and crossorigin once merged
Indeed.
I went through comments.
(did a force push)
I've merged this request into master with adjustments. Many thanks Andrew!
Thank you everyone!
Hi! What's up with this one? Are there any alternative approaches to get rid of eval I can consider?
I'll take another look.

I'm ready to contribute a substantial amount of time into resolving this issue.

My original concept was:
* add the RPC/RFC support
* create a new breed of CSP safe fetch based behaviors
* deprecate existing behaviors and let them die slowly over the years.

Then we can put this pull-request on-hold until these fetch-based behaviors are available.

Until then eval() will be needed anyways, so there's no need to use this new RFC invocation.

Well, the whole point of this PR was that ajax *could* be used with strict CSP if proper behaviours used. (some old ajax behaviours using evals won't obviously work)

Let me merge back the master and see how it works together with nonce stuff.
There was a commit in Wicket repo for this yesterday but for some reason GitHub didn't detect it and close the PR.
Be possible to have this change on v8.x ?

> Be possible to have this change on v8.x ?

I see no technical problem just applying the commit to 8.x.
Done!
Thanks!

Looks good to me. We had some custom logging asking for the name of the page class after the session had already been detached. We only noticed it in production with locked page exceptions - this would have made debugging much easier. 
@svenmeier I wonder if you can comment on why we only saw it very rarely. My theory was to do with unmounted pages: most of our pages are mounted and presumably resolving the page class uses some shortcut in code - without requiring a page lock. Resolving the name for unmounted pages does require a lock and caused the LockedPage exception on subsequent request. Does that sound reasonable? Our current fix only disables that (unnecessary) bit of logging -- and it seems to work -- but I wonder if I'm merely fixing a symptom of the real issue.
Hard to tell what might increase the likelihood of that happening. Perhaps you can pinpoint a specific version upgrade?

Yes, this concerns any JS that is added during an ajax call.
If a component has an attached AjaxBehavior, setting it visible is sufficient to trigger an JS evaluation - via AjaxCallListeners this might contain a plethora of JS snippets.

How would you 'register' all these?
Until each an every of these cases (in Wicket's code and all users' code) are migrated, you'll need <evaluate> and thus nobody will use this RFC feature.

@svenmeier please have a look at the proof of concept in my last commit.

Generally the issue is in header item being evaluated instead of added to the head, so what I did is made all header contributions in ajax to render these header items, also I added nonce support to the JS.

Essentially this can be used to replace all evals (as a legacy support feature). I don't think this approach is optimal, and ideally components should keep their JS in a JS file similar to what we do with properties and html file, these JS's will be rendered as header items and later used with some JS initialisation callback, or maybe with standard function.

Do you think it's a right direction?

cc @martin-g @solomax

IMO we can't *force* user to use this or that technique
We only can propose sort of best-practices
Short inline JS is already being used everywhere (including multiple wicket based libraries)

I believe remove or reduce eval usage is good thing
would it be smarter if we reuse the `<script>` element and replace only its body ? would the browser re-evaluate the new body ? I haven't tested yet

@martin-g I thought about using the same JS tag. This could work if we set an id to this script tag. The question is how we going to identify them? Component id wouldn't work, because component could have several different header items added in renderHead. Any ideas?

`console.time` can be used for benchmarking :)
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Console/time

BTW just stumbled on https://api.jquery.com/jQuery.globalEval/ - note that it supports a nonce option.

That function just forwards to https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/core/DOMEval.js, interesting how jQuery removes the item immediately.

Ah, yes.      (  ).

I think we can use jQuery.globalEval in wicket-ajax-jquery then. I'll push tidied code next week. 

Have a nice weekend, everyone!

>       (  )

well said! :-)
Thanks, @mattrpav !
Can this be closed now?
Thanks espyrop, I've applied the change with minor changes.

Thanks @espyrop I've applied the change.
Please close this pull request.
The script might contain multiple functions, each requesting a separate suspension. So it's safer to count them.
Created a new one for globalEval #384

This PR fixes the problem in WICKET-6704 but there are more classes in Java which do the same as PropertyChangeSupport, e.g. java.security.BasicPermission, java.util.BitSet, and one dozen more. Should we whitelist them too ? Or someone sees how to fix the problem in CheckingObjectOutputStream ?

If every JS snippet is ending up as a header item anyway, why not remove <priority-evaluate> and <evaluate> from the Ajax response and transport everything as a <header-contribution>?
In the correct order of course.

<script> and <style> already have a nonce-attribute, so we don't need to invent something new to transport that information in the Ajax response.
With WICKET-6703 we will have 4 paths* in wicket-ajax-jquery.js to add <script> to the DOM, which could all be unified:
```
[<header-contribution>]
-> processHeaderContribution	
  -> Wicket.Head.Contributor.processContribution
    -> processScript
      [has "src"]
        -> Wicket.Head.addElement
      [has "id"]
        -> addJavascript
          -> Wicket.Head.addElement
      [otherwise]
        -> jQuery.globalEval

[<priority-evaluate> or <evaluate>]
-> processEvaluation
  -> jQuery.globalEval
```

> If every JS snippet is ending up as a header item anyway, why not remove <priority-evaluate> and <evaluate> from the Ajax response and transport everything as a <header-contribution>?
> In the correct order of course.
> 
> <script> and <style> already have a nonce-attribute, so we don't need to invent something new to transport that information in the Ajax response.
> With WICKET-6703 we will have 4 paths* in wicket-ajax-jquery.js to add <script> to the DOM, which could all be unified:
> 
> ```
> [<header-contribution>]
> -> processHeaderContribution	
>   -> Wicket.Head.Contributor.processContribution
>     -> processScript
>       [has "src"]
>         -> Wicket.Head.addElement
>       [has "id"]
>         -> addJavascript
>           -> Wicket.Head.addElement
>       [otherwise]
>         -> jQuery.globalEval
> 
> [<priority-evaluate> or <evaluate>]
> -> processEvaluation
>   -> jQuery.globalEval
> ```

I think this could work. Just before I start with this, what do others think? @martin-g ? @solomax ?
Sounds good to me! In this case there won't be a need for `<meta><wicket-nonce/></meta>`
Related to: https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/385
Fixed with #385
+1 sounds very clear and straightforward :)

All right, I've implemented the stuff discussed above. All "evaluate" and "priority-evaluate" tags are now gone from AJAX XML as well as meta and wicket-nonce. I had to add a new attribute to JS header contributions to mark those which must be rendered after components.
Any thoughts on this? Should I proceed with cleaning up tests?
I've taken a short look only, but I have some changes already. It try to find some time soon.

Why do you think it cannot be null ? 
`org.apache.wicket.core.util.resource.locator.IResourceStreamLocator#locate(java.lang.Class<?>, java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.util.Locale, java.lang.String, boolean)` can return null. PackageResource will just wrap it in ProcessingResourceStream if it not null.
Thank you, @vrozkovec !
@martin-g Yes, you're completely right of course. Sorry for the noise...

IMHO I've found a better solution, see https://github.com/apache/wicket/commits/WICKET-6703-replace-eval-with-domEval

By taking the ordering of the items in <ajax-response> into account, we can simplify this a lot.
@svenmeier I had a look at the code. It all makes sense. I'll test it soon.
Thanks for the review!
Actually your data-wicket-evaluation=after made me wonder whether we could just make the ordering relevant. It's just a script of instructions that is processed in JS.

Hi @svenmeier !

`target.prependJavaScript((String.format("jQuery('#%s').fadeOut(500, Wicket.Ajax.suspendCall());", c3.getMarkupId())));` this line in demo certainly needs some explanation. At a first glance it's not very obvious where the suspension is released.

Somewhat like this:
`// suspendCall suspends the ajax queue here, also the suspendCall itself returns a function which does release a lock once called. The fadeOut will call this function when animation is finished and the lock will be released.`
Potentially the notify can be pulled into variable to make things clear.

Also, I think it would be nice to have a demo with multiple locks.

@andruhon I've seen that you preferred to put this into a separate js file. Personally I'd rather have this concise and *cool* :P

Regarding multiple locks - I don't know when/why this would actually be useful.

> Regarding multiple locks - I don't know when/why this would actually be useful.

Do we (want to) support it ?
If YES then let's test it whether it works.
If NO then let's document it and/or throw an error in JS code when a second suspend is called.

Many thanks Andrew, we've got this enhancement into master.
Please close this pull request.
Thank you everyone! Have a great weekend!

>If I open dialog with a Link in a new tab, it just blinks and disappears immediately (tested in FF, Chrome and Edge).
> This is a really annoying behavior. It's, probably, outside of the demo scope 

Yes, but this impacts all Ajax links opened in a new browser window. We don't have add a workaround for that here.

Hi! I've tested the new ModlDialog and it looks cool! I've found just a minor UI issue under Firefox opening different nested dialogs: the resizable right border of the underline dialogs is still active:

![Screenshot from 2019-12-07 20-56-45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/536912/70379960-50a1db80-1934-11ea-9fe2-ea6fd3a8b745.png)

The problem is not present using 'stacked dialogs' instead of 'nested'

Thanks Andrea for given the implementation a test!
I'm aware of the issue with the resize handle. It seems to be a bug in Firefox with nested resizable containers. Since this is just the example CSS, I don't care too much about it.
I just wanted to demonstrate, that we don't need huge JS anymore for such features.
@svenmeier Great! Give me a call when you are done, so we can proceed merging this PR.

@ivaynberg any objections against continuing the new modal dialog implementation on #375 ?
If not, could you please close this pull request?
no objections

> This is my take on a new modal dialog/window for Wicket.

Hi @svenmeier 

Have you had a chance to check out the way Modals work in the Wicketstuff ModalX project? It uses Wicket core Modal classes 'as is' but makes them much more easy to set up and use for the developer.

There may be some useful ideas in there that could improve the whole Modal experience for Wicket devs if brought into core Wicket.

The way Wicketstuff Modal X facilitates modal dialogs makes it very easy to open any modal dialog from anywhere in the app just by calling the constructor on the class of the modal you want to open and then calling show().

It supports nesting up to N levels. The 'N' can be specified by the dev.

Any page that needs modal simply needs to implement the org.wicketstuff.modalx.ModalMgr interface (typically you do this once in a commonly used base page class so that the whole app becomes Modal capable very easily).

The ModalMgr base class auto adds 'N' placeholder components to any page that it renders and these are then automatically allocated in sequence each time a new modal is nested upon another one. As the modals are closed the placeholders are freed up in reverse sequence until, when the last modal is closed, they are all freed up and the user can then proceed to open another top level modal etc.,
